liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
The Treasurer has turned to the NDIS now ‚Äî here's the full exchange with the ABC's Andrew Probyn. Andrew: You referenced before the $15 billion that you hope to save from lowering the growth of the NDIS and the seven years after that your ambition is for $59 billion in savings. So that's $74 billion all up. You talked about remembering the primary objective of the NDIS and Bill Shorten only this morning was saying it was designed for those who were severely disabled. Are we to deduce from this, and the fact that to get these savings, the federal government intends tightening eligibility for 
the NDIS? Jim Chalmers says the intention is to "moderate the growth in the cost of the scheme", adding that there is "broad recognition that changes need to be made in the NDIS". Chalmers: I think it's in everybody's interest that we do that because if you go back to that primary objective that you were kind enough to reference, if you overwhelming objective here is to provide for people who are relying on the scheme that Labor designed... then you got to make sure that it is 
affordable. And so Bill and the rest of the Cabinet will work closely with the NDIA and the sectors and the providers so thatthe cost of this scheme will grow quite quickly over the life of the next decade, but where we can moderate those cost increases. Because if we can do that we'll secure the future of the scheme at the same time we 
put the budget on a more sustainable footing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does the government intend to tighten eligibility for the NDIS?

And so Bill and the rest of the Cabinet will work closely with the NDIA and the sectors and the providers so thatthe cost of this scheme will grow quite quickly over the life of the next decade, but where we can moderate those cost increases.

Because if we can do that we'll secure the future of the scheme at the same time we 
put the budget on a more sustainable footing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
That question was just put to the Treasurer. Mr Chalmers says they've got "three parts of plan A", pointing to the Housing Australia Future Fund (which needs to pass parliament) and tax breaks for build-to-rent properties. Chalmers: These tax incentives with build to rent 
and for depreciation, they will make a difference. We will build more rental properties as a consequence of those policies. I was 
really proud, frankly, to include in the budget last night the biggest increase in rent assistance for three decades. And I know that that won't make the pressures in the rental market disappear but it will help people get through while we try to build more supply, which is our overwhelming objective when it comes to the housing market.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
The Treasurer has been asked about middle-income earners, and when they're likely to get a reprieve. Here's the full exchange: Reporter: John Howard had his battlers, Scott Morrison had quiet Australians, Kevin Rudd had working families. What do you call that group? And 
more importantly, given their taxes helped create that surplus last night, when will their household budgets get that bit easier? Jim Chalmers says he doesn't want to "carve up Australians in different groups and try to pit them against each other". Chalmers: We are genuinely trying to govern for the whole place. Sometimes that means giving extra help to people who are doing it toughest, but typically, we are trying to be a good, decent, middle of the road government which recognises the legitimate aspirations that people have in middle Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: When will 'middle Australia' see some relief in the budget?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant The federal budget revealed 1.1 million households will receive an increase in Commonwealth rent assistance. It will be boosted by 15 per cent, taking the maximum payment to $180 a fortnight for a single person. Most of the recipients are pensioners or those receiving Centrelink benefits. "It‚Äôs good, it‚Äôs important that it‚Äôs been raised,‚Äù says Homelessness Australia CEO Kate Colvin. ‚ÄúWhen people are struggling to put three meals a day on the table, every dollar makes a difference.‚Äù The increase has been budgeted at $2.7 billion over four years. But Colvin says an extra $15.50 a week won‚Äôt make much difference to how people feel about their ability to pay the rent. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just that rents have increased so much,‚Äù she says. A recent report from Anglicare found less than one per cent of private rental properties were deemed affordable. Before the budget, the Australian Council of Social Service had recommended doubling the Commonwealth rent assistance payment. Last week, the ABC spoke with 20-year-old Abby Manning, who until recently had relied on the Youth Allowance payment and Commonwealth rent assistance while studying at TAFE. After seeing the budget last night, she says the rent assistance increase wouldn‚Äôt make much difference. ‚ÄúI was hoping the government would take this as a chance to do something bigger and better,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúObviously I‚Äôm disappointed. I mean, it‚Äôs like two dollars a day.‚Äù
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget boost for rent assistance well below what advocates hoped for

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
That question was just put to Jim Chalmers, amid ongoing debate about the impact of the budget on inflation. The Treasurer says he doesn't pre-empt decisions made by the Reserve Bank board. Chalmers: Never have. Never will. Don't intend to do that today. The defining influence on our decisions around the cost of living package, our decisions around the growth package, and the historic 
restraint that we have shown in spending has been this inflation challenge. We are supremely confident that the budget that we handed down last night will take some of these cost-of-living pressures off without adding to inflation. The Treasurer says "such a big proportion of that spending in 23-24 is legacy issues that we had to clean up". Chalmers: The fact that the cost of living package 
only adds 0.1% of GDP in that period, the fact that our energy plan, the combination of the price caps and the bill relief takes three-quarters of a click off inflation next year. All of these things, I think, are important demonstrations for why so many of the bank economists in particular have come out today and said at 
worst the impact on the economy is neutral and many of them have said better than that. There won't be unanimity about that, you can always find if you look hard enough, you can always find a view on either side of the spectrum.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If the RBA increases interest rates, will the Treasurer be to blame?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Let's turn back to the National Press Club now, where the Treasurer is taking questions. First up, Jim Chalmers is asked why those who receive the single parenting payment won't benefit from the $40 increase to Jobseeker and other working-age payments. Chalmers: The $40 base rate increase to JobSeeker and some of the other working-age payments was all about addressing the lowest payments in the system. When it comes to [single] parenting payment, what we have done is quite dramatically expand the eligibility for that. What it means if you're on parenting payment single, the difference between that and JobSeeker is about $177 a fortnight. And so parenting payment single is already a higher rate, about 95% of the age pension as I 
understand it. We're expanding eligibility for it and introducing more generous income arrangements for it as well.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why aren't people who receive the single parenting payment included in the Jobseeker increase?

Chalmers:
The $40 base rate increase to JobSeeker and some of the other working-age payments was all about addressing the lowest payments in the system.
When it comes to [single] parenting payment, what we have done is quite dramatically expand the eligibility for that.

What it means if you're on parenting payment single, the difference between that and JobSeeker is about $177 a fortnight. And so parenting payment single is already a higher rate, about 95% of the age pension as I 
understand it.
We're expanding eligibility for it and introducing more generous income arrangements for it as well.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Everything‚Äôs coming up Milhouse for Australia‚Äôs tech sector, which has given the treasurer a thumbs up. They‚Äôve told national technology reporter Danny Tran that the budget is a welcome step after months of data breaches, cyber-attacks and sirens sounding over the power of artificial intelligence. Here's the latest from Danny: Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says the budget will allow Australia to keep pace with the rapid scale of advancement we‚Äôre seeing on the horizon. Misha: Unless we make those deep investments, we know that Australia will fall behind, will lose competitive advantage and that will come at a cost of Australian jobs and living standards, so the race is on to keep Australia at the forefront of an array of new frontier technologies. Cybersecurity has come away as a winner with the federal government announcing $101.6 million over the next five years to boost our cyber capabilities. That bucket of cash includes $46.5 million over four years to set up a Coordinator for Cyber Security, who will be tasked with making sure Australia can manage any cyber threats coming our way. On the domestic side of things, small businesses will also get a helping hand to defend themselves against cybercriminals with a new ‚Äòcyber wardens‚Äô program, which will cost about $23.4 million over three years. Cash will also be pumped into stronger privacy protections for Australians.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How‚Äôs big tech feeling about the budget?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
The Treasurer says improvements to the nation's short-term position won't make "all of our structural spending pressures go away". He says the NDIS and interest costs remain the most prominent issues, alongside health and defence and aged care. Chalmers: But those two fastest 
growing areas [NDIS and interest costs] are also now the most prominent areas of improvement and progress. Our commitment to banking revenue upgrades means we'll have $300 billion less debt, saving us around $83 billion of interest costs by the end of the medium-term. And while the commitments of the Prime Minister and the states on the NDIS 
will secure its future and reduce payments growth, this combined with some modest but meaningful tax changes to improve our revenue base, all of this has contributed significantly to a marked decline in the structural deficit by the end of the medium-term.

Chalmers: That's perennial... but our job is to make the right decisions for the right reasons. I think we have done that and I think we are doing that in the budget.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians are lucrative targets for scammers and the losses are enormous ‚Äì estimated at more than $3.1 billion last year. The budget has some support to help deal with this growing problem. Here‚Äôs more from national consumer affairs reporter, Michael Atkin: Michael: The federal government was alarmed by the record scam losses revealed last month and this budget has committed far more money to protecting Australians ‚Äì in total just over $86 million over four years. The stories of those who lose everything to scammers are devastating and the financial blow can impact a family for generations or cripple a business. Victims I‚Äôve interviewed express frustration that more isn‚Äôt being done to address gaps that are exploited by scammers on social media platforms, telco networks and in the banking system. Consumer groups have been pushing hard for banks to be made liable to repay scam funds, which they say would drive innovation. It‚Äôs something the sector has outright rejected, arguing it would reduce personal responsibility. The biggest ticket item in the budget is establishing a National Anti-Scam Centre to be run by the consumer watchdog, the ACCC ‚Äî a move first announced in November. We‚Äôre still waiting on the detail but the government says it will involve government, the big banks, telcos and others to prevent and disrupt scam activity. It also says industry will be held to account with tough new codes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: National Anti-Scam Centre to focus on billions lost to scams each year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Ryma Tchier for The World Today The head of a western Sydney charity group has dismissed the budget's cost-of-living measures as insufficient. Nafiye Mind runs the Blacktown Area Community Centres and her organisation is swamped with requests from people struggling with rising living costs. She told The World Today she was expecting more in the budget. "I just kind of wish we were doing a face to face interview so you could have seen my eyes roll, like if that's not token I don't know what is." "I can't imagine what significant difference that could make. $40 a fortnight, $20 a week. What groceries can an average person get for $20?"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cost-of-living relief little more than a 'token effort'

children.content: By Ryma Tchier for The World Today
The head of a western Sydney charity group has dismissed the budget's cost-of-living measures as insufficient.
Nafiye Mind runs the Blacktown Area Community Centres and her organisation is swamped with requests from people struggling with rising living costs.
She told The World Today she was expecting more in the budget.
"I just kind of wish we were doing a face to face interview so you could have seen my eyes roll, like if that's not token I don't know what is."
"I can't imagine what significant difference that could make. $40 a fortnight, $20 a week. What groceries can an average person get for $20?"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there anything for Carers in the budget?  - Angie. Thanks for the question, Angie! Here's what political reporter Jake Evans says: Hi Angie, people on the Carer Allowance will be eligible for up to $500 in energy bill relief - the exact amount depends on which state you live in. Grandparents who are full-time carers of grandchildren who are children of a veteran will also be made eligible for supports under the Defence, Veterans and Families Acute Support Package Act, which can include childcare, counselling, household assistance, school transport and other services. The single parenting payment is available to eligible carers and that scheme will be extended to include people with children up to 14 years of age, meaning they will receive a higher payment than they would if they were on JobSeeker. The $40 base rate increase being applied to a number of payments is not being applied to Carer Allowance.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Question: What's in the budget for carers?

children.content: Is there anything for Carers in the budget?
- Angie
Thanks for the question, Angie!
Here's what
political reporter Jake Evans
says:
Hi Angie, people on the Carer Allowance will be eligible for up to $500 in energy bill relief - the exact amount depends on which state you live in.

Grandparents who are full-time carers of grandchildren who are children of a veteran will also be made eligible for supports under the Defence, Veterans and Families Acute Support Package Act, which can include childcare, counselling, household assistance, school transport and other services.

The single parenting payment is available to eligible carers and that scheme will be extended to include people with children up to 14 years of age, meaning they will receive a higher payment than they would if they were on JobSeeker.
The $40 base rate increase being applied to a number of payments is not being applied to Carer Allowance.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The budget is just as much a political document as it is economic, but the key question is whether the government's second budget will quell or stimulate inflation. The prime minister says the budget takes pressure off families, while not adding to inflation, but he concedes that the job of reform is "never done". Meanwhile, those on JobSeeker will have to wait another four months when the $40 fortnightly increase kicks in at the end of September. "We are doing what we can, when we can, which is what we said we'd do," Anthony Albanese told RN Breakfast this morning. "We are providing that support for people alongside a range of other measures in this budget." You can listen to the prime minister's full interview on RN Breakfast with Patricia Karvelas here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM: The budget 'supports Australians across the board'

props.alt: Albanese smiles with the red budget tree blooming in the background.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's more from data journalist Catherine Hanrahan in New South Wales. The federal government have allocated $12 billion in the budget to rewire the nation to build an 82 per cent renewable grid by 2030. NSW will collect $4.7 billion of that funding to unlock transmission and Renewable Energy Zones in partnership with the NSW government. The state is also expected to be a beneficiary of the $2 billion allocated to the Hydrogen Headstart program, which the Albanese government says will ensure Australia becomes a renewable energy superpower. NSW has three hydrogen hubs in the Illawarra, Hunter and Wagga Wagga regions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick As Australia digests all the news from the federal budget, the Northern Territory is simultaneously sinking its teeth into its own budget papers, which also rolled out on Tuesday. NT Treasurer Eva Lawler‚Äôs inaugural budget features a massive infrastructure spend planned for the impending financial year, with $2.1 billion pegged mainly for the jurisdiction‚Äôs roads and housing. While the construction and mining sectors have applauded this year‚Äôs allocations, there‚Äôs not been any huge departmental increases put on the table for health, education or the NT Police force. The NT opposition, police union and territory‚Äôs social services council have all criticised the 2023 NT budget's priorities, saying more focus should've been placed on the region's most vulnerable. Opposition Leader Lia Finocchiaro said police were all but ignored in the middle of a "crime crisis".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Northern Territory budget spends big on roads and housing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is in the  Budget for the ABC? - Shane. Hi Shane, thanks for your question. We put it to political reporter Jake Evans: Hi Shane, this federal budget provided an additional $52.4 million over three years for the ABC and an additional $45 million over four years for the SBS, on top of $7.7 billion going to both national broadcasters over the next five years. Those additional payments are described as being for the ABC to continue to support local news and current affairs services, and for the SBS to continue to make news content available for Chinese and Arabic speaking communities in Australia.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Alexandra Humphries The maximum rate of Rent Assistance will increase by 15 per cent, or up to $31 per fortnight from September. Ben Bartl is the principal solicitor with the Tenant's Union of Tasmania has told The World Today any increase is welcome. "It's the biggest increase (in rent assistance) in more than three decades and it will provide cost of living relief for many Tasmanians," he said. But Mr Bartl says they won't fix a broken system. "It shouldn't be forgotten that rents across Tasmania have increased by $75 a week over the last two years. So while the increase (to assistance) will provide some cost of living relief, it doesn't go far enough."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tenant's Union of Tasmania: rent help not a game-changer

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Lara Corrigan and Wing Kuang Independent MP Allegra Spender said while the latest federal budget is "a pretty positive budget for climate", she believed it could have gone further. Spender also told ABC NewsRadio that she didn't think the additional $2.4 billion Petroleum Rent Resources Tax (PRRT), which is subjected to gas and oil companies, was "enough". "I think the PRRT reforms were a missed opportunity," she said. "Australia is unique in our resources and we need to make sure that the Australian taxpayers get the benefit from that." Spender also thought the household electrification incentives, which was to help Australians to move away from relying on gas, was "just a first step" to help reduce emissions and cost of living. "I think we need to go further, particularly in terms of giving households the tools and information to make some of this transition," she said. "Because it's not only money, it's also a tricky transition sometimes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Independent MP says the budget could have 'gone further' on climate

props.alt: Spender gestures while speaking.

children.content: (AAP: Dan Himbrechts)
Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Lara Corrigan and Wing Kuang
Independent MP
Allegra Spender
said while the latest federal budget is "a pretty positive budget for climate", she believed it could have gone further.
Spender also told ABC NewsRadio that she didn't think the additional
$2.4 billion Petroleum Rent Resources Tax
(PRRT), which is subjected to gas and oil companies, was "enough".
"I think the PRRT reforms were a missed opportunity," she said.
"Australia is unique in our resources and we need to make sure that the Australian taxpayers get the benefit from that."
Spender also thought the household electrification incentives, which was to help Australians to move away from relying on gas, was "just a first step" to help reduce emissions and cost of living.
"I think we need to go further, particularly in terms of giving households the tools and information to make some of this transition," she said.
"Because it's not only money, it's also a tricky transition sometimes."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any incentive in the budget regarding paying hecs/help sooner. Eg There used to be the 10% discount - Steve. Hi Steve, thanks for your question. I've passed it to political reporter Jake Evans who says: There's a big "TBC" over the whole higher education sector, because the government is currently in negotiations with unions, universities and others to develop a "University Accord". That deal would be very wide-ranging, looking not only at tertiary education funding and structure, but also at student loans and loan repayment. For now, there's no new incentive schemes or loan relief, besides a technical decision by the government to forgo $21 million worth of debt it would be owed over the next decade from loans issued in 2017 and 2018 under the VET FEE-HELP program, due to delays in the transfer of those loans to the Australian Taxation Office. It means students currently paying off loans face a 7 per cent increase on June 1 when they are indexed, which will add thousands more to many student debts.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Rachel Mealey Energy Consumers Australia says the subsidies announced for energy bills will hold back price rises. Chief executive Lynne Gallagher told The World Today the 36 percent prise-rise forecast in the October budget will now be lower. "I think what the government's really saying is that the measures that they brought in December have brought down coal and gas prices which are bringing down wholesale prices," she said. "And then if you factor in the additional money in this budget that's being matched by the states, if you take that into account, then what consumers will see is only a 10 per cent increase in their bill."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy consumers to see less severe hikes

children.content: Reporting by Rachel Mealey
Energy Consumers Australia says the subsidies announced for energy bills will hold back price rises.
Chief executive Lynne Gallagher told The World Today the 36 percent prise-rise forecast in the October budget will now be lower.
"I think what the government's really saying is that the measures that they brought in December have brought down coal and gas prices which are bringing down wholesale prices," she said.

"And then if you factor in the additional money in this budget that's being matched by the states, if you take that into account, then what consumers will see is only a 10 per cent increase in their bill."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Huw Morrisson is in his first year studying a science degree after spending some time working in nursing. He hopes to get into the wildlife biology space, but at the moment he's struggling to make ends meet, spending about half his weekly income on rent in his Brisbane share house. As the cost of living continues to soar, he's considering moving back in with his parents as he'll struggle to afford rising rental costs. " It's been real tough. Prices are going up for just about everything. Rent is also going up," he told News Breakfast. He's currently looking for casual work in nursing to supplement his income. He's receiving Centrelink payments, but it's not enough to cover the basics. "I don't have the money for new tyres, so I just have to not drive [my car], basically. It just sits here."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any support for Long COVID management in the budget? - Bluey. Hi Bluey üëÄ Thanks for writing in. I've put your question to political reporter Jake Evan s who says: There is no new money for long COVID management in this budget. However the federal government has committed $50 million for further research on long COVID to be paid through the Medical Research Future Fund. A parliamentary committee inquiry into long COVID and repeat infections was released just at the end of last month, which included recommendations for long COVID clinics to be established in some public hospitals, more support and education. The government is developing its national plan on long COVID which it says will consider the findings of that committee's inquiry, so we may see more on this in the future.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Alison Xiao for The World Today Mount Druitt-based GP Dr Kean-Seng Lim has told The World Today his patients will benefit from the government's tripling of the bulk-billing incentive payment for doctors. "In an outer Metro practice, we have a higher than average number of patients with healthcare cards, or those who are pensioners or those who are under the age of 16." "Were in a position where we were having to seriously consider charging a gap to all patients including pensioners, and cardholders, and this new measure will mean that we will now be able to continue to bulk bill, all the needy in our population."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By the Specialist Reporting Team's Loretta Florance: The government came into office with a mandate to improve Australia's environmental record, but conservation groups say while the budget has some promising measures on climate change, it doesn't provide nearly enough money to back the government's ambitious agenda to do more to protect the country's natural environment. The Australian Conservation Foundation's Kelly O'Shanassy welcomes investment in "climate action, renewable energy and clean exports", including $2 billion to speed up development of Australia's hydrogen industry and $1.3 billion towards energy efficiency in houses. "That's really important because Australians are struggling with the cost of living and investing in energy efficiency in homes," she says. There was also $121 million over four years to make good on the government's promise to set up a new national body, Environment Protection Australia (EPA), as well as another $51.5 million over four years for a new environment information agency. Ms O'Shanassy says that's "a good investment in forming a new agency". But the public is yet to see legislation to establish a national EPA, and the Wilderness Society's Tim Beshara says the government needs to get on with it. "The new EPA and a data collection agency is a good start for figuring out how we do address the problems that we're facing on the nature side," he says. "[But] I think that's a patch-up for where we should have been. I think that should have been in last year's budget and we should have been well advanced from where we're at right now to the reform agenda." Both groups also say the government hasn't put any significant new money behind its ambitious goal of zero extinctions. "There's nothing in this budget that is going to lead to additional species coming off the [endangered] list in the right way ‚Äî that is not becoming extinct, but actually becoming more and more common, less and less rare," Beshara says. "The Australian government has obligations for hundreds of species to have put in place a recovery plan and to fund that, and the backlog on writing those plans and implementing those plans and funding those plans is rising. "So, until there is dedicated additional substantive funding put into endangered species recovery, things are going to continue to decline. It's hard not to see we're going to have more extinctions [under] the Albanese government."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Conservation groups say the budget doesn't do enough for the environment

children.content: By the Specialist Reporting Team's Loretta Florance:

The government came into office with a mandate to improve Australia's environmental record, but conservation groups say while the budget has some promising measures on climate change, it doesn't provide nearly enough money to back the government's ambitious agenda to do more to protect the country's natural environment.

The Australian Conservation Foundation's Kelly O'Shanassy welcomes investment in "climate action, renewable energy and clean exports", including $2 billion to speed up development of Australia's hydrogen industry and $1.3 billion towards energy efficiency in houses.
"That's really important because Australians are struggling with the cost of living and investing in energy efficiency in homes," she says.
There was also $121 million over four years to make good on the government's promise
to set up a new national body, Environment Protection Australia (EPA)
, as well as another $51.5 million over four years for a new environment information agency.
Ms O'Shanassy says that's "a good investment in forming a new agency".
But the public is yet to see legislation to establish a national EPA, and the Wilderness Society's Tim Beshara says the government needs to get on with it.
"The new EPA and a data collection agency is a good start for figuring out how we do address the problems that we're facing on the nature side," he says.

"[But] I think that's a patch-up for where we should have been. I think that should have been in last year's budget and we should have been well advanced from where we're at right now to the reform agenda."
Both groups also say the government hasn't put any significant new money behind
its ambitious goal of zero extinctions

"There's nothing in this budget that is going to lead to additional species coming off the [endangered] list in the right way ‚Äî that is not becoming extinct, but actually becoming more and more common, less and less rare," Beshara says.

"The Australian government has obligations for hundreds of species to have put in place a recovery plan and to fund that, and the backlog on writing those plans and implementing those plans and funding those plans is rising.

"So, until there is dedicated additional substantive funding put into endangered species recovery, things are going to continue to decline. It's hard not to see we're going to have more extinctions [under] the Albanese government."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any information about the eligibility criteria for the $500 energy relief? Everywhere I read it says there will be a $500 relief for energy bills for eligible households but no information as to who is eligible. - John. Hi John. Here's the lowdown from political reporter, Jake Evans: The energy relief payment will be available to pensioners, veterans, seniors and other concession card holders, as well as recipients of Carer Allowance, Family Tax Benefit and anyone eligible for existing state and territory electricity concession schemes. However, the amount you receive will differ from state to state, as the money is jointly funded and the federal government has had to strike eight different deals with each state and territory. $500 will be offered in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania $350 in total relief will be available in Western Australia and the territories $650 will also be available to eligible small businesses in states that have matched the relief.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Questions from you: Who is eligible for energy bill relief?

children.content: Is there any information about the eligibility criteria for the $500 energy relief? Everywhere I read it says there will be a $500 relief for energy bills for eligible households but no information as to who is eligible.
- John
Hi John. Here's the lowdown from political reporter, Jake Evans:

The energy relief payment will be available to pensioners, veterans, seniors and other concession card holders, as well as recipients of Carer Allowance, Family Tax Benefit and anyone eligible for existing state and territory electricity concession schemes.
However, the amount you receive will differ from state to state, as the money is jointly funded and the federal government has had to strike eight different deals with each state and territory.
$500 will be offered in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania
$350 in total relief will be available in Western Australia and the territories
$650 will also be available to eligible small businesses in states that have matched the relief.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tim Callanan Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has taken a swipe at previous Liberal federal governments in his reaction to last night's federal budget. Andrews said there were positive signs in the budget for Victoria, declaring "the decade of rip off is over." "You can‚Äôt fix nine years of neglect in just one budget but there are good positive signs, but we‚Äôll keep the pressure on, of course, because we want to get our fair share," he said. Mr Andrews said the health initiatives announced last night were "a good first step" in improving medical care across the country. "National Cabinet agreed earlier this year that health is the number one issue and it was very pleasing to see significant investments ‚Äì not everything ‚Äì but a big next step in last night‚Äôs federal budget. "Particularly, longer consultations, higher payments to GPs and higher rebates particularly for vulnerable people. This is all about a better primary care system." Andrews said he would discuss more moves to reform the health system at a health-only National Cabinet meeting before the end of the year. There was no money allocated last night towards the 2026 Commonwealth Games, which Victoria is hosting in regional centres, but the Premier said that doesn‚Äôt mean there won‚Äôt be a federal contribution. "The Commonwealth Games is not happening next week so we do have time and we do have some optimism that the Albanese government will be a partner," he said.

There were no new measures for universties this budget ‚Äî but expect more to come in the future.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A number of cost-of-living measures announced in yesterday's budget will apply to pensioners. More than 5 million households will have up to $500 deducted from their power bills in the next financial year. This will apply to pensioners, Commonwealth Seniors Health Card holders, Family Tax Benefit A and B recipients and small business customers of electricity retailers. The government is also increasing the Medicare levy low-income thresholds for singles, families and seniors and pensioners from July 1, 2022, which means more people will be exempt from paying the Medicare levy in their 2022-23 tax returns. For medicines, the budget includes a $2.2 billion increase to access for medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ChatGPT has declined to comment. But here's national technology reporter, Danny Tran: Artificial intelligence is getting a boost, with the federal government tipping in $101.2 million over the next five years to help businesses integrate AI and quantum technologies. That includes expanding the National AI Centre and its role in making sure the technology is responsible (I, Robot, anyone?) as well as setting up the Australian Centre for Quantum Growth. Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says this type of investment is important: "Every time anyone enters a prompt or an instruction into ChatGPT or a generative AI tool, it is hoovering that up and building a complex profile about us. "So [it is] really important that we diligently deepen our investments in ethical and responsible use of AI and the sort of safeguards around privacy and copyright and security on generative AI tools." Simon Bush from the Australian Information Industry Association, the peak body for the information and communications technology sector, says we have a "very limited" opportunity to get this technology right. "We are competing with our trading partners, both friendly and not so friendly, in relation to areas like AI and Quantum," he says. "This funding enables smaller Australian innovative companies to access government support, to commercialise their IP and their technology, to really bring that to the market and also [retain] really smart people, so [we] don't lose them overseas. "It‚Äôs a really good down payment on securing Australia‚Äôs future."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hey ChatGPT, is there any money in the budget for artificial intelligence?

But here's national technology reporter, Danny Tran:

Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says this type of investment is important:
"Every time anyone enters a prompt or an instruction into ChatGPT or a generative AI tool, it is hoovering that up and building a complex profile about us.

"So [it is] really important that we diligently deepen our investments in ethical and responsible use of AI and the sort of safeguards around privacy and copyright and security on generative AI tools."

Simon Bush from the Australian Information Industry Association, the peak body for the information and communications technology sector, says we have a "very limited" opportunity to get this technology right.
"We are competing with our trading partners, both friendly and not so friendly, in relation to areas like AI and Quantum," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Julie Edwards from Jesuit Social Services. She says while the budget includes some positive investments to tackle the cost of living, the increase to the Jobseeker payment will do little to lift vulnerable people out of poverty. Julie: We know that many aspects of the cost of living are at near-record highs, including rental prices, petrol, groceries and other essentials, which makes it even less sustainable for a Jobseeker recipient to live a dignified life. We saw during the pandemic that increased payments reduced measures of poverty and housing stress, but a very modest increase of $2.80 per day will sadly make little difference to many. Our political leaders must create a fair social safety net that ensures all Jobseeker recipients can afford an adequate standard of living.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Anna Pykett and Wing Kuang Nationals leader David Littleproud has slammed the federal government for introducing a new fresh food tax for farmers to cover biosecurity costs. The federal budget announced a 10 per cent increase in agricultural levies to fund biosecurity activities and organisations, expecting it to raise $153 million over three years. Littleproud told ABC NewsRadio this was an "outrageous move". "They are going to tax farmers to pay for the biosecurity costs of their competitors to import product into this country, and that has to be passed on to the consumer," he said, adding it would not help address food price inflation. He also said regional Australians would have few benefits from Labor's cost-of-living package, stressing what was needed in regional Australia was infrastructure and new childcare places. He was also concerned that new Medicare boosts would lead to the closure of regional pharmacies, meaning regional Australians might face more accessibility issues in the future. "We feel like the forgotten Australians," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nationals slams Labor for new tax on regional Australians

"They are going to tax farmers to pay for the biosecurity costs of their competitors to import product into this country, and that has to be passed on to the consumer," he said, adding it would not help address food price inflation.

He was also concerned that new Medicare boosts would lead to the closure of regional pharmacies, meaning regional Australians might face more accessibility issues in the future.
"We feel like the forgotten Australians," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has criticised Labor's spending in the budget, and said it doesn't address the root cause of inflation. The budget offers a $14.6 billion cost-of-living package, including a $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker, which the Liberal Party hasn't yet taken a position on. "Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: That's inflationary," he told RN this morning. "What we needed was a budget that was going to take pressure off inflation, in the process then take pressure off interest rates, and of course that helps everybody. "That's why the right budget to unite Australians, to help all Australians was a budget that was going to take those pressures away." You can listen to the Shadow Treasurer's full interview on Radio National with Patricia Karvelas here.

"Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: That's inflationary," he told RN this morning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Jemima Burt Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland. This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects. But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing. "Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs ‚Ä¶ If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said. She said despite modest rises to welfare payments, there are many Queenslanders who will continue to live in poverty. "There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment. "Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.

That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the government‚Äôs energy bill relief plan. Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people. ‚ÄúThere's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,‚Äù she said. However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be ‚Äútough‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,‚Äù she said.

children.content: By Tim Callanan
Victorian social services groups have cautiously welcomed ‚Äúmodest‚Äù increases in support in the federal budget for people struggling with the cost of living crisis.
That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the government‚Äôs energy bill relief plan.
Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people.

‚ÄúThere's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,‚Äù she said.
However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be ‚Äútough‚Äù.
‚ÄúWe've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,‚Äù she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Amanda McKenzie, CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary. McKenzie: This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower people‚Äôs power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables. Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks. The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Climate Council says budget is 'a warm up lap in history's most important race'

children.content: Amanda McKenzie,
CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary.
McKenzie:

This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower people‚Äôs power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables.

Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks.

The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By state political reporter Keane Bourke There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector. Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful. Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit ‚Ä¶ below the $500 going to those along the east coast. From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some post-Budget Day photos from outside Parliament House

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan. Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year. This time around, NSW will get $362 million over eight years, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning. There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program. The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for infrastructure projects in NSW?

props.alt: A builder smooths out concrete.

children.content: (ABC News: Chris Gillette)
Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan.

Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year.
This time around, NSW will get
$362 million over eight years
, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning.
There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program.
The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market  - Josh. Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year. The federal government committed in that budget to $324.6 million over four years to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government. The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Questions from you: What happened to the Help to Buy scheme?

children.content: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market
- Josh
Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter
Jake Evans
who says:
The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year.
The federal government committed in that budget to
$324.6 million over four years
to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government.
The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Of course we do. They have been legislated," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "We went to an election promising it, as did the prime minister. And there's about 17 broken promises now that the prime minister sits on and surely he's not going to add this one to the list as well. "I think they come in at the right time. They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment. "But I do think as you come out of the inflationary period, you do want to provide support to families who are still going to have massive electricity and gas bills to pay under Labor's policies.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does the opposition continue to support stage 3 tax cuts?

children.content: "Of course we do. They have been legislated," Dutton tells News Breakfast.

"I think they come in at the right time. They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment.
"But I do think as you come out of the inflationary period, you do want to provide support to families who are still going to have massive electricity and gas bills to pay under Labor's policies.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We'll have more to say about that Michael tomorrow night and some other measures as well," Dutton replies. liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's it for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's interview on News Breakfast. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is now taking questions from host Michael Rowland. He says the Labor government gets "a tick" for the budget being back in the black, but says it should credit the Coalition for that win. "If they had been gracious, they should acknowledge they inherited a good set of figures," Dutton says. "They obviously had a surge of income, and they have spent some of that wisely, but there's a lot of extra taxing spending that is going to be inflationary. "I worry for those families who are missing out and who are really hurting at the moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Labor inherited 'a good set of figures'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "There's money there for the referendum, which is right because we have a referendum coming up, but also $10.5 million in mental health support for Indigenous Australians in the referendum period. What does that say about the impact that this debate is having on First Nations people?" News Breakfast host Michael Rowland asks. "Well, it is having a difficult impact," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "There are words that are used these days on social media and in other forms often anonymous, sometimes not frankly, some of the things that are being said in this debate are hurtful. "We're very conscious of the pressure which Indigenous Australians will be under. We know that when the vote, the postal ballot was held on marriage equality, then people in that community felt under pressure as well and we have been conscious about that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Stage three tax cuts will cost $69 billion over four years, our cost of living package comes in at $15 billion. Can you see how some people out there ‚Äî perhaps more than some people ‚Äî would see a massive disconnect?" Michael Rowland asks. "Well, they, of course, were legislated some time ago. They're included in the budget as they have been for some time and we have no plans to change those measures. We haven't given consideration to that," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese replies. "Do you see how some people see $69 billion for tax cuts targeting in large part wealthy Australians compared to only $15 billion for cost of living?" Rowland repeats. "Those measures begin at $45,000. If you're on $45,000, watching this program, you don't regard yourself as being wealthy," Albanese replies.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "You revealed the cost of the stage 3 tax cuts will be $69 billion over four years, four times the cost-of-living package. What is right about that picture?" News Breakfast presenter Michael Rowland asks Treasurer Jim Chalmers. "I was asked yesterday how much they'd cost and because there's an extra year of these cuts in the forward estimates, it's a bigger number than it was last name," Chalmers said. "You can see the disparity between the figures and how that would be viewed by people. "First of all, those tax cuts kick in at $45,000 and it's important that we give back some of the bracket creep in the jargon, particularly to people on low and middle incomes, but we haven't changed our position on the stage 3 tax cuts. "What we've done in the budget last night is to provide some help for people who are doing it toughest, the most vulnerable people in our community and that shows where our priorities are. "We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers pressed on stage 3 tax cuts

"We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In case you missed it: The higher JobSeeker rate for older people, which previously applied to recipients over 60 who had received JobSeeker for 9 months or longer, will now apply for recipients over 55. It means people aged 55 to 59 will receive an additional $92.10 per fortnight above what they receive today. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says "it's a really important change." "One of the most concerning parts of the community of Australians who can't find works is over-55s and particularly women over 55 ," he told News Breakfast. "The advice that we receive from the expert committees we set up is that this is a big and growing challenge for us. It is harder and harder, particularly for women over 55, to get back into work. Big increases in homelessness and the like and we've tried to provide extra help there."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers explains reason for changing JobSeeker age threshold

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's the question that's just been posed to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The JobSeeker base rate is increasing to $40 a fortnight, which breaks down to an extra $2.85 a day. "We've tried to do as much as we can without blowing the budget and adding substantially to inflationary pressures in the economy," Chalmers told News Breakfast. "I understand and respect that there will be people who say that we should do more. There will be people who say we shouldn't have done any of this. "We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases. "You need to look across the cost-of-living package."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is that JobSeeker increase the best a wealthy country can do?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast. "But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers calls budget surplus a 'complex balancing act'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the extra $2.85 a day for JobSeeker is "not enough to buy a loaf of bread". "Labor promised no-one would be left behind. The budget leaves millions of people behind, giving tax cuts to the politicians and billionaires while every day people on Jobseeker are left in poverty," he told ABC News Breakfast. Bandt added that "5.5 million renters get absolutely nothing out of this budget". "Those lucky to get rent assistance might get a dollar a day. Rents in capital cities have been growing 10 times faster than that. "Labor doesn't understand how severe the rental and housing crisis is. People are sleeping in tents and cars. People are spending 60 per cent of their income on rents."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bandt says extra JobSeeker money 'not enough to buy a loaf of bread'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BCA chief says government delivered 'solid budget' but opportunities were missed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you weren't up frantically refreshing the blog all night (unlikely), here are a few of the key announcements you should know about: There will be $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, including help with power bills, reduced health costs and creating more affordable housing The government is allocating $11.3 billion to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages An extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for J obSeeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients Bulk-billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with children under the age of 16, pensioners and other Commonwealth concession card holders The maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance will be increased by 15 per cent

There will be

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By the Specialist Reporting Team‚Äôs Loretta Florance Environment minister Tanya Plibersek has defended the budget against criticism it doesn‚Äôt do enough to back up the government‚Äôs ambitious threatened species agenda. Some environmental campaigners say much more cash is needed to tackle a backlog of conservation plans for endangered species, which are up for review. But Ms Plibersek said they have "already locked in funding to protect our precious threatened species". Plibersek : In the October Budget we committed $224.5 million for our Saving Native Species Program. We‚Äôre already rolling out these commitments, including over $70 million for koalas. And this budget includes almost $440 million through the Natural Heritage Trust for programs to conserve threatened species and ecosystems and restore Ramsar wetlands. She also says new funding for national parks and urban rivers will give ‚Äú46 per cent of threatened animals and 25 per cent of threatened plants that live in our cities and suburbs have a real chance of survival‚Äù. But conservation groups say it‚Äôs going to take much more money to stop extinctions in Australia. ‚ÄúWe need to invest about $2 billion a year over 30 years to end the extinction crisis and repair nature. There's nowhere near that,‚Äù the Australian Conservation Foundation‚Äôs Kelly O‚ÄôShannasy said. The minister also said the government would release legislation for public consultation on a new national EPA this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Nowhere near' enough money to tackle 'extinction crisis', environment groups say

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
The Treasurer has turned to the NDIS now ‚Äî here's the full exchange with the ABC's Andrew Probyn. Andrew: You referenced before the $15 billion that you hope to save from lowering the growth of the NDIS and the seven years after that your ambition is for $59 billion in savings. So that's $74 billion all up. You talked about remembering the primary objective of the NDIS and Bill Shorten only this morning was saying it was designed for those who were severely disabled. Are we to deduce from this, and the fact that to get these savings, the federal government intends tightening eligibility for 
the NDIS? Jim Chalmers says the intention is to "moderate the growth in the cost of the scheme", adding that there is "broad recognition that changes need to be made in the NDIS". Chalmers: I think it's in everybody's interest that we do that because if you go back to that primary objective that you were kind enough to reference, if you overwhelming objective here is to provide for people who are relying on the scheme that Labor designed... then you got to make sure that it is 
affordable. And so Bill and the rest of the Cabinet will work closely with the NDIA and the sectors and the providers so thatthe cost of this scheme will grow quite quickly over the life of the next decade, but where we can moderate those cost increases. Because if we can do that we'll secure the future of the scheme at the same time we 
put the budget on a more sustainable footing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does the government intend to tighten eligibility for the NDIS?

Andrew Probyn
Andrew:

You referenced before the $15 billion that you hope to save from lowering the growth of the NDIS and the seven years after that your ambition is for $59 billion in savings. So that's $74 billion all up.

You talked about remembering the primary objective of the NDIS and Bill Shorten only this morning was saying it was designed for those who were severely disabled. Are we to deduce from this, and the fact that to get these savings, the federal government intends tightening eligibility for 
the NDIS?
Jim Chalmers says the intention is to "moderate the growth in the cost of the scheme", adding that there is "broad recognition that changes need to be made in the NDIS".
Chalmers:

I think it's in everybody's interest that we do that because if you go back to that primary objective that you were kind enough to reference, if you overwhelming objective here is to provide for people who are relying on the scheme that Labor designed... then you got to make sure that it is 
affordable.

And so Bill and the rest of the Cabinet will work closely with the NDIA and the sectors and the providers so thatthe cost of this scheme will grow quite quickly over the life of the next decade, but where we can moderate those cost increases.

Because if we can do that we'll secure the future of the scheme at the same time we 
put the budget on a more sustainable footing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
That question was just put to the Treasurer. Mr Chalmers says they've got "three parts of plan A", pointing to the Housing Australia Future Fund (which needs to pass parliament) and tax breaks for build-to-rent properties. Chalmers: These tax incentives with build to rent 
and for depreciation, they will make a difference. We will build more rental properties as a consequence of those policies. I was 
really proud, frankly, to include in the budget last night the biggest increase in rent assistance for three decades. And I know that that won't make the pressures in the rental market disappear but it will help people get through while we try to build more supply, which is our overwhelming objective when it comes to the housing market.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does the government have a 'plan B' to tackle pressures on the housing market?

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Virgin Australia says IPO planning advanced, finalising capital return
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Planning for Virgin Australia's upcoming initial public offering (IPO) is "well advanced", chairman Ryan Cotton said on Wednesday in an internal email that also outlined bonus payments to the airline's shareholders and staff after a return to profit. Cotton said Australia's second-biggest airline was days away from finalising a capital return. Investors led by US private equity firm Bain Capital will share a $730 million payment, according to Reuters, citing a source who was not authorised to speak publicly. It will be structured as a capital reduction rather than a dividend, with Bain Capital taking around 90% followed by Richard Branson's Virgin Group with 5% and the rest going to the remaining shareholders, the source added. A Virgin Australia spokesperson confirmed the contents of the internal email. A Bain Capital spokesperson declined to comment. The airline had sought up to $450 million of loans for the capital return, Reuters reported in March. The rewards to staff and shareholders come as Virgin Australia, the key domestic rival to Qantas, prepares for what is likely to be one of the country's biggest listings this year. "I can also confirm the IPO planning is well advanced," Cotton said in the email to staff seen by Reuters. "While there is still no date set and our ultimate window of opportunity will depend on market conditions, we are hopeful this process will progress over the coming quarters," he added. Virgin Australia chief executive Jayne Hrdlicka said on Monday that she would take several weeks of leave to spend time with family after the death of her husband from cancer. In an email drafted before her departure that accompanied Cotton's, she said the payments to staff and shareholders reflected the "monumental feat" of returning the airline to profitability for the first time in more than a decade. Bain Capital bought Virgin Australia in 2020 after it was placed in voluntary administration.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Banking and oil stocks drag ASX lower
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: On a day that the Australian share market is down slightly, healthcare (+0.9) and real estate (+0.8%) are some of today's best performing sectors. They are being driven higher by shares of Telix Pharmaceuticals (+2.8%), Mirvac (+2.2%) and Growthpoint Properties (+1.9%). On the flip side, the financials (-0.8%) and energy (-0.5%) are today's weakest performers. It comes after steep falls in the shares of Bank of Queensland (-4.5%), NAB (-4.1%), Santos (-1.2%) and Beach Energy (-1.9%).

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX slips ahead of US inflation figures
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Australian share market is struggling to advance today, ahead of some hotly-anticipated inflation figures from the United States that could determine whether the world's biggest economy cuts interest rates later this year. By 1:10pm AEST, the benchmark ASX 200 was down 0.2% to 7,253 points. The Australian dollar was steady at 67.6 US cents. US consumer price inflation figures (for the month of April) will be released at 10.30pm AEST. Economists expect the headline CPI to hold steady at an annual 5% and core CPI to moderate very slightly to 5.5%. But if inflation turns out to be sticky (or higher than those estimates), it would conflict with market bets that US rates will fall. Meanwhile, US President Joe Biden and top lawmakers failed to break a deadlock over raising the $US31.4 trillion debt limit, but vowed to meet again with just weeks before the country may be forced into an unprecedented default.
